rComments: good professor, knows his stuff. happy there was no textbook to pay for, weekly readings posted as pdfs online. not a hard course, but attending lectures and tutorials a must to get a good grade. learned a lot about the islamic world, would definately recommend prof Nejatis course.

Alright. So I took NMC103: The Islamic World with Dr. Nejatie and found the course to be really interesting in terms of the material. It was the prof's first time teaching the course and he didnt do too bad of a job. The assignments arent't super clear, basically you just have a reading and are supposed to write an essay about it.

Prof Nejatie was one of the best profs I've had through my undergrad and NMC373 was my favorite course by far. The lectures were clear and easy to follow, and there was plenty of room for participation. He is also the nicest prof ever (he brought us Persian sweets for Norouz), and was very fair with grades and deadlines. Take his class if you can!

Ridiculously dense course with no textbook, just endless readings scattered throughout numerous journals. Very vague writing assignments, which would definitely confuse and screw over any first years. Even as an NMC student I regret taking this course.
teacherRatingTags: ['Lecture heavy', 'Lots of homework', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: Sajjad Nejatie is passionate towards what he teaches however, the reading loading is way too high, and material is dry. Teaching a course regarding Islam, he tends to disregard the fact that displaying images of the Prophet is highly offensive and uses images frequently. Often explains too many details and leaves out what we need for assignments
